My brother and I are both atheist, he is a Marine and I am enlisting with the Army next wednesday. His tags state "no preference", even though he clearly stated atheist as his preference. content: I hate this assumption that, as service members, we are all assumed to be A. Conservative and B. Christian. Last spring, we had a civilian maintainer with a "Jesus" hat on getting the ice off of the windshield of our helicopter. We were on a military airfield and I was extremely bothered by it. If I did, I'm sure someone would say something because it is assumed that we are A and B as described above.

content: quote: Originally posted by 11933037: I hate this assumption that, as service members, we are all assumed to be A. Conservative and B. Christian. Last spring, we had a civilian maintainer with a "Jesus" hat on getting the ice off of the windshield of our helicopter. We were on a military airfield and I was extremely bothered by it. I chose not to say anything because I was being evaluated and didn't want to start the flight off of the wrong foot. I don't go to work with a "There is no God" hat on. If I did, I'm sure someone would say something because it is assumed that we are A and B as described above. You make a lot of interesting points here: 1) We atheists don't where our beliefs on our sleeves, hats, necklaces, or anywhere else visible. This is out of respect for regulations and for others. There's really nothing stopping us and we might just start. 2) Most traditional religious people do where their religion on crosses around their necks or other clothing. This is prohibited in the military, technically, just for uniformity. 3) The civilian has personal clothes on and is really not beholden to military regulations, so on the one hand maybe he did nothing wrong (unless he was actually a DA Civilian employee and then maybe). 4) The overt act of announcing one's beliefs in the workplace has an immediate disruptive effect. You, seeing that, felt out of place by having to hide your beliefs, felt it unfair that that person had privileges that you do not, and you might have been drawn into a debate about religion. He is declaring his Christianity and maybe you want to declare your beliefs. You might do this for no other reason that to avoid being lumped in with Christianity. This 'lumping' and 'assumption of conformity' and 'silence is agreement' mentality leads to total fairytales like the idea that the military is 90% Christian as is sometimes suggested. Then people think it's ok by virtue of supermajority to ignore others and heap special privileges on the supposed majority. Unless we want to instigate intractable arguments about belief and cause one or more groups of individuals to feel persecuted, everyone needs to focus on work and keep their personal agenda to themselves (and not advertise it overtly). Jason

content: You're probably not old enough to remember what I like to call 'sh*t on shirts.' The thing used to be, when I was a kid, you never discussed your religion or politics. Nobody had a shirt with anything written on it unless they were in a ball game and the number identified them for the refs and the crowd. When, exactly, did people become human billboards and posters for everything from their favorite sneaker to their choice of god? My best tees and sweatshirts still are unmarked, black or gray. I do own other, chattier shirts, but they were usually bought at a price below the price of a good, unmarked tee or given to me by someone else. If you can keep the package inside looking and thinking okay, you don't have to worry so much about what's on the outside... that's my motto.
